thread.title: Gunvor Offers Bond Buyback After Asset Sales Net $1.7 Billion
thread.title_full: Gunvor Offers Bond Buyback After Asset Sales Net $1.7 Billion - Bloomberg Business

author: Andy Hoffman
title: Gunvor Offers Bond Buyback After Asset Sales Net $1.7 Billion
text:
Gunvor Group Ltd. offered to buy back all of its outstanding $500 million bond as the commodity trader deployed part of its cash hoard after selling assets in Russia.
The offer was triggered by Gunvor’s sale of oil terminal and pipeline assets in Russia, from which it earned a net profit of about $1.7 billion, the company said Tuesday in a filing with the Singapore Stock Singapore Exchange. A “significant portion” of the asset sale proceeds was paid out through an “extraordinary restricted payment,” which could include shareholder dividends, it said.
The yield on the 2018 notes fell 152 basis points to 8.15 percent after the offer was announced.
Gunvor will offer the full price for all outstanding notes that were part of its debut $500 million bond sale in May 2013. The trader already holds $154 million of the notes, it said.
“We have good liquidity and cheaper forms of financing available so it made sense to do it now,” Seth Pietras, a spokesman for Gunvor in Geneva, said by phone.
The yield on the notes climbed to more than 10 percent on March 21, 2014, the day after Gunvor co-founder Gennady Timchenko was sanctioned by the U.S. for his ties to Vladimir Putin. The yield peaked at more than 14 percent in December.
Gunvor, which followed rival Trafigura Beheer BV in selling bonds to fund purchases of physical assets, has been reorganizing since Timchenko sold his 44 percent stake to co-founder Torbjorn Tornqvist the day before the sanctions were announced. The company, which has denied any links to Putin after getting its start trading Russian oil, has sold most of its assets in the country, including the Ust-Luga petroleum product terminal.
Seeking Acquisitions The company, one of the world’s five-largest independent commodity traders, bought back $80 million of the bond in April.
Gunvor is now seeking to acquire assets outside of Russia including refineries and mines in Europe, North America, Africa and Asia. The company, which already owns two refineries in Europe, is “looking very actively on the investment side,” Chief Financial Officer Jacques Erni said in April.
Gunvor’s cash reserves rose by 56 percent to about $1.5 billion last year and operating profit jumped 20 percent to $432.4 million as volatility and a contango market structure boosted earnings from oil trading.
Chief Executive Officer Tornqvist, a Swedish national, now controls about 87 percent of Gunvor’s equity and all of the 15-year-old company’s voting shares. He has said Gunvor’s ownership is too concentrated and will seek partnerships or investors. A group of Gunvor employees own the remaining equity.
